Opinion: what is a museum to the struggles for independence in mexico doing in the alhondiga de granaditas which was initially a grain storage facility in 1803 miguel hidalgo y costilla took over the parrish church of our lady of sorrows in the settlement that today bears his name dolores hidalgo on september 16th 1810 the priest realized that the revolutionary plot had been discovered and decided to take the offence by ringing the church bell and summoning the townsfolk to action now referred to as the shout for independence or el grito later that month on sept 28 miguel hidalgo and ignacio allende would take possession of alhondiga de granaditas with the help of the celebrated local miner called el pipila juan jose de los reyes martinez amaro his image overlooks the town of guanajuato and is also at the entrance to san miguel de allende unfortunately the offence that started with the shout in dolores hidalgo turned into a protracted fight that ultimately ended in hidalgos own death and that of his revolutionary compatriots juan aldama ignacio allende and jose mariano jimenez their heads were hung in the four corners in the grain storage facility to serve as a bitter warning against civil disobedience from october 14 1811 up till the declaration of independence from spain in 1821 so in case you hadnt noticed i am including a photo i took today of one of the corners with the hidalgo plate and appears to correspond to the corner where hidalgo would have been grimly exhibited inside of the structure is a nice historical museum that exhibits many facets of this independence struggle and mexican history buffs will find it quite interesting

Titulo: i am glad i can read write and speak spanish
Opinion: it is really hard to get english information in many of these museums and this is one of them i first saw this museum while i was taking a guided tour with a small group i immediately liked the feel of the building upon viewing it from the small bus i had been trying to come here for 2 days but there were alot of school groups i finally came to see and learn about it this afternoon i learned that hidalgo and his other insurgents had their decapitated heads on display for all to see when they were caught and arrested for starting our mexican revolution there is alot of history of guanajuato here from pre columbian times until the early part of the 20th century the usual indian artifacts from the region like the zapotecs are on display there is one room that i really enjoyed it is the art and craft room that shows the different products made in this region among them are the quartz jewelry the pottery the unique clothes and so on i was not even aware that there was so much mining here i also saw some learned that the state of guanajuato has his own cowboy he mostly wears a kind of scraf instead of a hat but i am from a hot place the history of the mexican revolution is described in detail since this is where miguel hidalgo had his first victory there are very detailed murals on each of the stair ceilings of the mexican revolution and suffering encountered by my ancestors i am glad i came here because i got to review some of my history and what my ancestors had to go through to get our independence there are a few other artists and photograhers that have their work displayed on the second floor these rooms are worth visiting because you can get to view the way my mexican people looked and dressed in the past in the courtyard there is a copy of the campana de independencia along with some material used in the mining industry here there is still some active mining done in the area but i heard that some canandian proprietors own the mines if you are here to visit come and view this historical museum on the history of guanajuato

Titulo: human heads were hung in cages of the four corners of this building for all to see
Opinion: overall great place if youre a bit of a history buff and a great place to take pics this place was built by the spaniards to store grains it was only used for that purpose for less than a year before being turned into a fort was overtaken by miguel hidalgo and the rebel insurgents to start the mexican independence later was taken back by the spaniards after being captured and killed hidalgo was decapitated and his head along with the heads of four other major leaders of the revolutionary movement hung in cages from the four corners of the alhondiga the museum has a great layout of the timeline and highlights of mexicos road to independence from the spaniards along with some great exhibitions paintings photography sculptures on display inside the different rooms of the museum the murals on the walls painted by jose chavez morado have a resemblance to the murals painted in the national palace of mexico city by diego rivera and have a lot of detail and symbolism

the alhondiga de granaditas in 1810 was the scene of one of the epic battles of the mexican war of independence an army of 20000 soldiers lled by the miguel hidalgo father of the mexican of the great epic besieged a spanish and criollo force of around 600 men the alhondiga served as a granary and depository of seeds and is a huge and at least by 19th century standards very defensible building the attacking force ultimately broke in by burning down the door and a massacre of the defenders ensued later hidalgo and three other leaders of the independence forces were tracked down and murdered by the avenging spanish and their heads were hung on the four corners of the alhondiga the building later in its history served as a prison until 1949 and today is a museum that celebrates the history of guanajuato for those interested in photography there is a terrific collection of the photos of early twentieth century studio photographer romualdo garcia torres for the historically minded their is a welldesigned set of displays tracing guanajuato from its origins as a colonial mining town to the present

Titulo: un gran museo en un edificio historico un lugar ideal para las lecciones de la historia de mexico
Opinion: muy buen museo de la historia de mexico y guanajuato hablando de los principales hitos del desarrollo historico de mexico a partir de las muestras de ceramica precolombina a la exposicion de la artista local del siglo 20 se presta especial atencion a la exposicion de la guerra de la independencia el importante papel que recayo en guanajuato museo examen comienza con el examen de la gigante moore cuenta la historia guanhuato en una sala separada describe los acontecimientos de mas de 10 anos de guerra con imagenes de los lugares emblematicos y sus instigadores y heroes en la parte inferior del hall of fame con enormes cabezas de los principales luchadores por la independencia y una llama eterna muy agradable sala de manualidades ceramica tejidos bordados encajes productos de hierro forjado productos de madera sesion de fotos pagado 30 pesos

Titulo: un imprescindible cuando vayas a guanajuato

Opinion: edificio construido a finales del siglo xviii en tiempos del virreinato se utilizaba en un principio como almacen de granos fue uno de los primeros y principales escenarios de la lucha por la independencia de mexico ya que durante el ataque por el ejercito insurgente a la ciudad de guanajuato en su interior se refugiaron familias peninsulares y se acuartelaron las tropas realistas por lo que fue asediado por las tropas rebeldes capitaneadas por miguel hidalgo y costilla el 28 de septiembre de 1910 gracias a un personaje apodado el pipila el guajolote que cubriendose la espalda con una losa de piedra pudo atravesar el fuego enemigo y llegar hasta las puertas del edificio que tras ser incendiadas fue tomado este hoy en dia este edificio alberga el museo regional de guanajuato

Opinion: this former granary where an important battle took place during the 1810 war of independence has been transformed into a museum the buildings exterior is very plain except for a few dramatic spots where cannon balls hit but the interior is quite grand in a series of alcoves on the lower level are busts dedicated to martyrs such as allende and hidalgo who died here while fighting against the spanish the murals along the staircases tell the story of this seminal moment in mexican history our visit to the museum would have been better had we been able to find an english speaking guide on site

Titulo: dont let the exterior discourage you this is a great place
Opinion: this fortress like building which served as a granary and then as a fortress and then as a jail and now as a museum turns from a formidable block of stone into a lovely interior courtyard that has been remade into a museum of the mexican war of independence in addition there are excellent collections of local prehispanic artifacts and remarkable stairway murals every bit is strirring as those in mexico city but it is the history of the war of independence that is worth the time as someone who knew very little i was fascinated by how complex it was guanajuato was the starting point and the alhondiga a site taken by the rebels and then lost to the loyalists major figures in the war were executed here or had their heads hung on hooks which still project from each corner of the edifice an imposing memorial for the key heroes fills one side of one floor there were also exhibits about local history which were well displayed and lots of signage but all in spanish but not especially dfficult to translate we intended to spend an hour and actually left 2 12 hours later look for the bullet scars on the exterior walls and do not overlook the loca craft exhibit which is on the left just before you leave

in 1810 the people of mexico rose up against their spanish opressors and thus began the mexican revolution led by the charismatic father miguel hidalgo the revolutionaries invaded the city of guanajuato only to find that the spanish had all sought refuge in the alhondiga granaditas the towns grainery made of impenetrable stone the alhondiga was a virtual fortress offering the spanish protection and an offensive position to shoot at anyone approaching them it looked like the revolutionaries were out of luck until a local miner nicknamed el pipila stepped up to the challenge strapping a large stone to his back pipila avoided the shots from the spanish as he approached the wooden door to the fortress he then burnt down the door allowing the mexicans to come inside seeking justice for all the wrongs done to their people over the centuries the alhondiga granaditas was the site of the first major battle of the mexican revolution today you can tour the alhondiga and the mexican history museum housed there a real must see if you want the history of guanajuato and the area known as el bajiothere is nothing like being able to feel the bullet holes in the walls to bring history to life
